Roll remaining dough large enough to cover filling. Seal edges together.
Snip surface of the dough with scissors to let steam escape.
Cover, let rise in warm place until doubled (about 1 hour).
Bake in moderate oven (375°F) about 35 to 40 minutes, or until done.
Let cake cool in pan. Frost while warm with confectioners' sugar frosting.
Cut into squares to serve.

improved_recipe.name: Frosted Pineapple Yeast Bars
instructions: Make the filling: In a saucepan, whisk together 1/2 cup sugar, cornstarch, and 1/4 teaspoon salt.
Stir in the lightly beaten egg yolk and the entire can of undrained pineapple chunks.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens and comes to a boil.
Remove from heat and let cool completely.
Make the dough: In a large bowl, combine 1 1/3 cups flour, 1 teaspoon sugar, and the yeast.
In a small saucepan, heat the milk, water, and margarine or butter over low heat until warm (120-130°F). The margarine doesn't need to melt completely.
Add the warm liquid to the flour mixture and beat with an electric mixer for 2 minutes at medium speed.
Add the 4 egg yolks and 1/2 cup flour. Beat at high speed for 2 minutes.
Stir in enough of the remaining flour to make a soft, slightly sticky dough.
Divide the dough in half. On a lightly floured surface, roll out half the dough to fit the bottom of an ungreased 15x10-inch jelly roll pan.
Spread the cooled pineapple filling evenly over the dough.
Roll out the remaining dough to the same size and place it over the filling. Pinch the edges to seal.
Use scissors to snip small vents in the top crust to allow steam to escape.
Cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, about 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 35-40 minutes, or until golden brown.
While still warm, make the frosting by whisking together the confectioners' sugar and enough milk to make a drizzling consistency.
Drizzle or spread the frosting over the warm bars.
Cool completely in the pan before cutting into squares.

original_recipe.name: Gingerbread Men Cookies (Old Fashioned Spicy)
instructions: Early in the day: In a large bowl beat first 11 ingredients (all but the 5-6 cups flour) until just mixed.
Increasing speed to medium, beat 2 more minutes.
Using a wooden spoon, stir additional 5 to 6 cups of flour into dough to make it stiff.
Divide dough in half and wrap in plastic wrap.
Refrigerate for up to two days.
Preheat oven to 350° F.
Roll half the dough until 1/8" thick.
Cut with gingerbread man cookie cutter.
Bake 12 minutes until cookie edges are firm.
Cool. Decorate.

improved_recipe.name: Old-Fashioned Spicy Gingerbread Men
instructions: In a large bowl, beat together the brown sugar, margarine, eggs, and molasses on low speed until just combined.
Add the 3 cups flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, allspice, cloves, and ginger. Increase speed to medium and beat for 2 minutes.
Using a wooden spoon, stir in 5-6 cups additional flour, 1 cup at a time, until the dough is very stiff and no longer sticky.
Divide the dough in half, wrap each half tightly in plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or up to 2 days.
When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Working with one portion at a time (keep the other refrigerated), roll the dough out on a lightly floured surface to 1/8-inch thickness.
Cut out gingerbread men using cookie cutters and place on the prepared baking sheets, spacing 1 inch apart.
Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until the edges are firm and the centers are set.
Cool on the baking sheet for 2 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
Decorate with royal icing, raisins, candies, or as desired.

original_recipe.name: Sugar Cookies (Alice Carle's)
instructions: Mix well, then refrigerate two to three hours, or overnight before rolling.
Roll out to desired thickness.
Cut into any desirable shape.
Put on a baking sheet that has been coated with a nonstick vegetable spray.
Bake at 350° F for ten to eleven minutes.

improved_recipe.name: Classic Cut-Out Sugar Cookies
instructions: In a large bowl, beat the margarine and confectioners' sugar together until light and fluffy.
Add the egg, vanilla, and almond extract. Beat until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, cream of tartar, baking soda, and salt.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture, mixing until just combined.
Divide the dough in half, wrap each half in plastic wrap, and refrigerate for at least 2-3 hours or overnight.
When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or coat with nonstick spray.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the dough to 1/4-inch thickness (or thinner for crisper cookies).
Cut into desired shapes with cookie cutters and place on prepared baking sheets.
Bake for 8-11 minutes, or until the edges are just barely golden.
Cool on the baking sheet for 2 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack.
Decorate with icing, sprinkles, or enjoy plain.

original_recipe.name: Springerle (Preferred Recipe)
instructions: Sift flour with baking soda, set aside.
With electric mixer, beat eggs until very light.
Add powdered sugar, a tablespoon at a time and continue beating until mixture resembles a soft meringue (at least 15 minutes with a mixer).
Add anise oil and grated lemon rind.
Blend in sifted flour mixture.
Cover tightly and let stand 15 or 20 minutes.
Roll out small portion at a time to 1/4" thickness.
Press floured springerle mold into dough.
Cut cookies apart.
Place on un-greased flat trays. Cover with a towel and let dry at room temperature overnight.
In the morning, transfer cookies to a cookie sheet coated with nonstick spray and sprinkled with crushed anise seeds.
Bake in pre-heated 300° F oven ten to fifteen minutes.

improved_recipe.name: Traditional Springerle Cookies
instructions: In a large bowl, beat the eggs with an electric mixer on high speed until very light and thick, about 5 minutes.
Gradually add the confectioners' sugar, 1 tablespoon at a time, and continue beating for at least 15-20 minutes total until the mixture is very thick, pale, and resembles a soft meringue.
Beat in the anise oil (or extract) and grated lemon zest.
Sift together the flour and baking soda.
Gently fold the flour mixture into the egg mixture until just combined. The dough will be soft.
Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and let the dough rest at room temperature for 15-20 minutes.
Divide the dough into manageable portions. On a lightly floured surface, roll out one portion at a time to 1/4-inch thickness.
Dust a springerle mold or rolling pin with flour and press it firmly into the dough to imprint the designs.
Cut the cookies apart along the lines and place them on ungreased baking sheets or trays.
Cover the cookies with a clean kitchen towel and let them dry at room temperature overnight (8-12 hours). This allows the designs to set.
The next day, preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Lightly grease baking sheets and sprinkle with crushed anise seeds. Transfer the cookies to the prepared sheets.
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the cookies are set but still pale (they should not brown much).
Cool completely on wire racks. Store in an airtight container for several weeks to mellow and develop flavor.

original_recipe.name: Brown Sugar Brownies
instructions: Cream sugar and butter. Add other ingredients (except nuts). Mix well.
Stir in nuts.
Spread in thin layer on cookie sheet that has been lightly coated with a nonstick vegetable oil.
Bake at 325° F for 20 minutes.
Cut while warm.

improved_recipe.name: Brown Sugar Pecan Brownies
instructions: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Lightly coat a 9x13-inch baking sheet or jelly roll pan with nonstick spray.
In a medium bowl, cream together the brown sugar and margarine or butter until light and fluffy.
Beat in the egg and vanilla until well combined.
In a small bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture and mix until just combined.
Fold in the chopped pecans.
Spread the batter in a thin, even layer on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake for 18-20 minutes, or until the edges are set and lightly golden.
Remove from oven and cut into bars while still warm.
Cool completely on the pan before removing.

original_recipe.name: Chocolate Oat-Chip Cookies

ingredients.item: Quaker Oats (quick or old fashioned, uncooked)

instructions: Heat oven to 375° F.
Beat margarine and sugars until creamy.
Add eggs, milk, and vanilla; beat well.
Add flour, baking soda and salt; mix well.
Stir in oats, chocolate morsels, and nuts; mix well.
Drop by rounded measuring tablespoonfuls on un-greased cookie sheet.
Bake 9 to 10 minutes for a chewy cooky or 12 to 13 minutes for a crisp cookie.
Cool one minute on cookie sheet; remove to wire rack. Cool completely.

improved_recipe.name: Chewy Chocolate Chip Oatmeal Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a large bowl, beat the margarine or butter with both sugars until light and creamy.
Add the eggs, milk, and vanilla. Beat until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture and mix until just combined.
Stir in the oats, chocolate chips, and nuts (if using) until evenly distributed.
Drop dough by rounded tablespoons onto ungreased cookie sheets, spacing about 2 inches apart.
Bake for 9-10 minutes for chewy cookies, or 12-13 minutes for crisp cookies.
Let cool on the baking sheet for 1 minute, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

original_recipe.name: Cranberry Orange Relish
original_recipe.subtitle: Best if stored 2-3 days before eating
instructions: Slice un-peeled oranges into eighths, remove seeds.
Grind the cranberries and orange slices in a meat grinder.
Stir in sugar to desired sweetness.
Store in refrigerator for two or three days before eating for best results.

improved_recipe.name: Fresh Cranberry Orange Relish
instructions: Rinse the cranberries and pick over to remove any stems or soft berries.
Scrub the orange well. Cut it into 8 wedges and remove any seeds, but leave the peel on.
If using a food processor: Pulse the cranberries and orange wedges together until finely chopped but not pureed. If using a meat grinder: Grind the cranberries and orange wedges through the grinder.
Transfer the mixture to a bowl and stir in sugar to taste, starting with 3/4 cup and adding more if you prefer it sweeter.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 2-3 days before serving to allow the flavors to meld.
Serve as a condiment with turkey, chicken, or ham. Keeps refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

original_recipe.name: Ice Box Pickles
instructions: Take 18 pounds of fresh cucumbers; scrub well. Either cut in one-half inch CHUNKS, or process as whole cucumbers.
Soak for four days in one and one-half gallons of water to which has been added one cup of pickling salt. Cover with plate and weigh down.
Rinse and slice, then mix three ounces of alum in enough water to cover cucumbers. Cover, and keep in refrigerator overnight.
Drain and rinse. Then soak cucumbers in enough (about one gallon) of 5% white vinegar to cover, for six hours.
Drain and save vinegar for use later.
Place pickles in crock with seven to ten pounds of sugar and one-half box of pickling spices. Stir and turn the chunks until all of the sugar is dissolved.

improved_recipe.name: Refrigerator Pickles
instructions: Scrub the cucumbers well and cut into 1/2-inch chunks, or leave whole if small.

Dissolve 1/4 cup pickling salt in 6 cups water. Pour over cucumbers in a large bowl or crock. Place a plate on top and weigh it down to keep cucumbers submerged. Let sit at room temperature for 4 days.
Drain and rinse the cucumbers well.
Dissolve 1 tablespoon alum in enough water to cover the cucumbers. Cover and refrigerate overnight.
Drain and rinse again. Place cucumbers in a clean container and cover with about 4 cups white vinegar. Let soak for 6 hours.
Drain the vinegar (you can save it for another use).
In a large crock or container, layer the cucumber chunks with the sugar and pickling spices. Stir and turn occasionally until all the sugar dissolves.
Cover and refrigerate. The pickles will be ready to eat in 2-3 days and will keep refrigerated for several weeks.

original_recipe.name: Kool-Aid Jelly
instructions: Pour water into saucepan. Add Kool-Aid and Sure-Jell, stirring until dissolved.
Heat mixture until it comes to a rolling boil.
Add sugar quickly, stirring constantly. Continue to cook until mixture returns to a boil.
Remove from heat. Skim. Pour into hot, sterile jelly jars.

improved_recipe.name: Kool-Aid Jelly
instructions: Sterilize 3 half-pint jelly jars and lids by boiling them in water for 10 minutes. Keep hot until ready to use.
Pour 3 cups of water into a large saucepan. Stir in the Kool-Aid powder and Sure-Jell until completely dissolved.
Bring the mixture to a rolling boil over high heat, stirring constantly.
Add all 3 cups of sugar at once. Stir constantly and bring back to a full rolling boil.
Boil hard for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Remove from heat and skim off any foam from the surface.
Quickly ladle the hot jelly into the hot sterilized jars, leaving 1/4-inch headspace.
Wipe the rims clean, seal with lids and rings, and let cool. The jelly will set as it cools.
Store in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks, or process in a boiling water bath for 5 minutes for shelf-stable storage.
